title: Introduction

author: Tijl De Bie, Department of Engineering Mathematics, University of Bristol

segmentation: Welcome to the Workshop on practical theories for exploratory data mining.
We thought very carefully about every single word in the title, so I'll explain that in.
In a minute.

Now I think this is actually quite a dangerous topic for a workshop for many reasons, and the main reason is that it's it's workshop topic that can drift very easily and that is very open to interpretation, so I would like to start by explaining what I think the topic of the workshop is, not about what exploratory data mining and this virtual specifically is not about.
Namely, it's not about data mining, that is, data mining methods and problems that are defined by a clear objective or a clear utility function.
Or by other types of goals that the user of the data mining tool may have.
So for example, it is not encompassed prediction problems like regression and classification.
And I also note problems like reinforcement learning and things like.

Now the reason why we didn't want to discuss it here is first of all, because we need to limit the scope of it the second because we think that there are lots of theories already dealing with say, prediction problems and reinforcement learning and problems in general where.
The objective is very clearly defined.
So what is it then?
Well exported to data mining as we define it here in this in this topic in this workshop is about facilitating the search for interesting Nuggets of information in the data.
And those negative information we will refer to as pattern.

So whenever I say pattern I really mean something found in the data that represents the relation or some some negative information and the goal of this would be to give serendipity chance so people don't wouldn't know what exactly they were looking for in the data when they do exploratory data mining, they just want to see what I could stumble upon if it might be interesting for them or not.
So they want to find new information, something that maybe surprises them or something that maybe they can exploit in some way, but they wouldn't know in advance how exactly they would exploit it.
And I think it is that is defining for exploratory here.

So in a way it is very similar to what statisticians what's called exploratory data analysis, but I would say that exploratory data mining would allow for greater complexity, say in the types of patterns we are looking for in the types of data we are looking at, and so on.
But other than that, it's really very similar to exploratory pattern exploratory data analysis.
OK, now the the motivation for the workshop is really that exploratory data mining we think is still very much an art and the question is can we make it assigns.
Can we make it such that this becomes a technology rather than something that you have to become really good at by say doing a PhD in it and then you can apply it in applied context.
But if you haven't done significant research on it, you simply cannot use it properly.
OK, now just to to structure this workshop a bit.

We thought about how we could identify maybe separate components and exported to data mining and the first component we thought was the pattern SYNTAX, which is very strongly connected with data type.
The structure of the data.
So the pattern SYNTAX really is the form of the patterns that we are looking at.
What types of things are we looking for?
We don't know exactly instances of those battles in Texas, which that's what we're looking for, but we need to define somehow the form of what we're looking for.
The second component is interesting.
This matters.
How do we quantify how interesting pattern of that's indexes?
Given something that we might know in advance.
The third component is efficient search.
Given that we know the syntax, we know how to quantify how interesting a pattern of that syntax is.
How do we find it efficiently?
And the 4th important component we think exporter data mining has is.
The fact that we need to visualize those patterns we need to present them at least maybe not visualizing, but at least presenting it in a useful and convenient way to the users.
There may be different components, for example evaluation of different methods an you may be able to think of more, but the four I listed first sort of ones that we were going to focus on most today.
And most of all, even the 1st three is the last one, not so much.
Hey, let me briefly talk about each of these components, an individually to make clear what we think the issues are and where we could potentially make some progress.
So pattern syntax.
Again, I stress the fact that pattern for us is a negative information.
Or you could think of it.
Some people would call it a data mining result.
So pattern is something defined very generally not in the limited definition used by people in the frequent pattern mining community or pattern means something else.
OK, so examples of pattern syntax is that we all know, or for example, a cluster.
The fact that there is a cluster present in the data, or maybe a whole clustering, maybe partition of the data.
Now I'm saying this very informally, but really, if you want to.
Mathematically defined, the patterns index of a cluster.
We need to specify this much in a much more details very obviously so.
In fact there are many ways in which people have specified pattern syntax is that somehow represents a cluster or a clustering of the data.
The second example that does come from the pattern mining community is a tile or a tile in a database, which really is is very similar to the fact that an item sets in binary data matrix is frequent.
Or the Association between set of attributes and Target label.
Which is really.
The case we have in problem is known as subgroup discovery.
Anne maybe.
In more complex types of data, the Association between different entities in a in a relational database or maybe different entities in a graph.
Maybe attributes of those entities in a graph, and so on.
So you can see there must be plenty of ways to specify patterns.
Indexes in such complex data.
OK, so we think that somehow we make to make progress in exported data mining and making it less of an arts and more of a signs.
We think that we need a very powerful language to describe patterns, indexes of those types and you see the diversity is very large, so that means it needs to be powerful.
And more importantly even we think it needs to be easy to use for non experts.
So it should be possible for an expert to somehow specify.
OK this is the kind of thing I'm interested in and they should be able to make the translation from that intuitive notion of.
Syntax they have in mind to a mathematical and rigorous specification of the pattern in the language that we need to conceive.

OK, so given that we have this syntax, we don't need to be able to quantify how interesting a pattern of that syntax is, because typically you can find lots and lots of patterns of that syntax in your data, and we need to be able to present them usefully and maybe in a certain rank order to the data miner.
Now, the most common approach to quantifying how interesting.
Pattern is by means of what some people would call objective interestingness measures.
An in clustering, for example, that would be the K means objective is a very typical example.
Or maybe the eigenvalue in spectral clustering and or lots and lots of other spectral clustering approaches.
Maybe mixture of Gaussians I would be would be the likelihood function.
So there are lots of different objective interestingness measures for clustering that people have devised.
And sometimes one may be more suitable than another one.

In itemset, mining is started off with frequency, but since done lots of people have identified and defined often more useful alternatives, there are also objective interesting this measures for item sets.
For Association rules, the subgroup discovery, we have a large number of them, maybe one of the most well known was is awaited relative accuracy.
There are lots more.
And I'm not even mentioning relational databases an graphs because.
Maybe little early days so we don't have very much research in those areas yet, but no doubt if research progress is will have flows and lots of different interesting this measures there.
On the other hand, wrist, there is a research effort to define what I would call subjective interestingness measures and other people call it this way too, which are interesting.

This measures that somehow try to take the prior information of the user into account as well, so they don't say, OK, I can define interesting this in an objective way in a universal way that will hold true for everyone, but I did find it which Spectre specific user with.
The users own background information or background beliefs.

And probably there are two main approaches in this area and one is based on the statistical testing which is based on computing the significance of a pattern given a reasonable reasonable background model.
An an effect I will talk about it in his keynote talk an another line of research is based on information theoretic approaches, which is something we have been working on quite a bit.
But there are strong connections between those.
Those two approaches in fact.

Now I should state just as a disclaimer, I'm not going to show any references in this introduction just for the sake of brevity, but we intend to make a long list of relevant relevant references available online on the virtual website.
So if you have anything that you think we should include in that list, feel free to let us know now, or maybe after the workshop.

Which is OK.

We have the interestingness, which may depend on the context, may depend on the user, so that's a lot of a lot of freedom we have there in.

Defining the problem really so that means that if we now need to be able to search for those most interesting patterns of those syntaxes, we needed totally automated framework for searching for those that is also extremely flexible, and ideally also rarely much less efficient than the most efficient algorithm that could be made for it.
OK, so maybe this is this is the least important.
Constraint on on the type of framework I would I would say, but it's obviously a very difficult one as well.
OK, now a number of examples and maybe not everyone would agree that this fits in this component, but I think one can argue about it.
So inductive databases somehow a paradigm that I was I think I may be wrong, but look will tell us.
I think will somehow made to hide the search from the user completely to kind of automate it in some way.
At least it was the ambition.
I think the declarative data mining completely fits into this.
Then there are all these exhaustive search approaches, mostly device in the pattern mining community started off with level by search and pattern sampling.
There are some interesting results on maybe we shouldn't try to exhaustively mine all the patterns of that syntax, but just sample them in an intelligent way, and there may be more different.
Generic approaches to the search problem or frameworks or paradigms maybe?
And the last component we want to highlight.
This is the component of presenting these patterns to the user in a way that allows interaction as well.
And the way in a way that is as intuitive as possible and somehow in a way that allows navigating the parallel space as effectively as possible.
And obviously that's a very tricky thing, because as I started by pointing out that.
Exploratory data mining is for the situation when we don't really know what exactly we're looking for.
We know the syntax maybe of what we're looking for.
Maybe we can define interesting, but we don't really know what to expect.
We don't really know what exactly to look for.
It's very different when you want to make a classifier you don't know what the accuracy is going to be of the classifier, but at least you want you know what you want to achieve.
In this case we don't know, so that makes navigation of the battle space is very tricky thing, because we don't know which which way to navigate.
The guy has some as an interesting paper on the topic as well.
I don't know if you will speak about it.
On the concept of navigability of battle spaces.
So I don't think people covered this very much in this workshop, but I think it's nonetheless very.
Very interesting that request for a generic solution to this to this problem.
Visual analytics and visually controllable data mining or two related areas of research that aimed to address this components and I think more than in the other three components.
This is still very much in art and effect in HTML PKD this year.
Daniel came gave a keynote talk and he was quite open about the fact that this is totally an artstyle.
And if somebody wants to.
So your company is interested in deploying visual Analytics to investigate our data.
He cannot tell them.
Look here is a tool.
Use it what you can tell them is OK if you want our expertise.
Can are you?
You can use our our time in our resources and we will make it for you, but that's very different.
I think it's not like a tool is available that people can just deploy and use.
OK, this one slide with a list of what I would call partial data mining frameworks.
I think nobody has yet attempted to make a universal framework covering all these different components.
I think this is what I would call framework.
They somehow cover one or several of these components, and I mentioned most of them in one of the previous slides.
So inductive databases, declarative data mining, is mostly about search.
Then certainly search paradigms as well, obviously is about the last components.
MDL, I haven't mentioned, but it's a generic approach for quantifying.
Interestingness, I would argue mostly for quantifying.
Objective, interesting us, but I think not everyone would agree.
I think some people would say that you can use it for subjective interesting as well.
Then the testing for interestingness, probabilistic modeling and statistical relational learning and also logical relational learning they.
One could probably argue that they can be used for defining complex and useful patterns in taxes, and maybe also for covering the search component to some extent.
OK, just a brief overview of the schedule.

Be useful in showing some imports and use cases where I think and also some some extending my experience.
